  • Constructor Details

    • PZeros

      public PZeros(double[] coef)
      Constructor that takes an array of real coefficients. Coefficients are supplied in order of increasing power. Example: p(x) = A + B*x + C*x^2 + D*x^3 + E*x^4 gives coefficients[] = {A, B, C, D, E}. The degree of the polynomial is equal to the length of the supplied array minus 1.
      Parameters:
      coef - An array of real coefficients in order of increasing power.

    • PZeros

      public PZeros(String[] coef)
      Constructor that takes an array of real coefficients. Coefficients are supplied in order of increasing power. Example: p(x) = A + B*x + C*x^2 + D*x^3 + E*x^4 gives coefficients[] = {A, B, C, D, E}. The degree of the polynomial is equal to the length of the supplied array minus 1.
      Parameters:
      coef - An array of real coefficients in order of increasing power.

    • PZeros

      public PZeros(DoubleDouble[] coef)
      Constructor that takes an array of real coefficients. Coefficients are supplied in order of increasing power. Example: p(x) = A + B*x + C*x^2 + D*x^3 + E*x^4 gives coefficients[] = {A, B, C, D, E}. The degree of the polynomial is equal to the length of the supplied array minus 1.
      Parameters:
      coef - An array of real coefficients in order of increasing power.

    • PZeros

      public PZeros(double[] coef_re, double[] coef_im)
      Constructor that takes an array with the real part of coefficients and an array with the imaginary part of the coefficients. Coefficients are supplied in order of increasing power. Example: p(x) = A + B*x + C*x^2 + D*x^3 + E*x^4 gives coefficients[] = {A, B, C, D, E}. The degree of the polynomial is determined by the length of the longest supplied array. If the longest supplied array has N elements, then the degree of the polynomial equals N-1. The shorter array is extended with zero values for the higher powers. E.g. a polynomial with arrays {1,2,3} and {11,22,33,44,55} has degree 4 and can be written as (1+11i) + (2+22i)*x + (3+33i)*x^2 + 44i*x^3 + 55i*x^4
      Parameters:
      coef_re - An array containing the real part of the coefficients in order of increasing power. If the supplied array equals null, then the degree is determined by the length of the other array and the real part of all coefficients equals 0 in that case.
      coef_im - An array containing the imaginary part of the coefficients in order of increasing power. If the supplied array equals null, then the degree is determined by the length of the other array and the imaginary part of all coefficients equals 0 in that case.

    • PZeros

      public PZeros(String[] coef_re, String[] coef_im)
      Constructor that takes an array with the real part of coefficients and an array with the imaginary part of the coefficients. Coefficients are supplied in order of increasing power. Example: p(x) = A + B*x + C*x^2 + D*x^3 + E*x^4 can be created with coef[] = {A, B, C, D, E}. The degree of the polynomial is determined by the length of the longest supplied array. If the longest supplied array has N elements, then the degree of the polynomial equals N-1. The shorter array is extended with zero values for the higher powers. E.g. a polynomial with arrays {1,2,3} and {11,22,33,44,55} has degree 4 and can be written as (1+11i) + (2+22i)*x + (3+33i)*x^2 + 44i*x^3 + 55i*x^4
      Parameters:
      coef_re - An array containing the real part of the coefficients in order of increasing power. If the supplied array equals null, then the degree is determined by the length of the other array and the real part of all coefficients equals 0 in that case.
      coef_im - An array containing the imaginary part of the coefficients in order of increasing power. If the supplied array equals null, then the degree is determined by the length of the other array and the imaginary part of all coefficients equals 0 in that case.

    • PZeros

      public PZeros(DoubleDouble[] coef_re, DoubleDouble[] coef_im)
      Constructor that takes an array with the real part of coefficients and an array with the imaginary part of the coefficients. Coefficients are supplied in order of increasing power. Example: p(x) = A + B*x + C*x^2 + D*x^3 + E*x^4 can be created with coef[] = {A, B, C, D, E}. The degree of the polynomial is determined by the length of the longest supplied array. If the longest supplied array has N elements, then the degree of the polynomial equals N-1. The shorter array is extended with zero values for the higher powers. E.g. a polynomial with arrays {1,2,3} and {11,22,33,44,55} has degree 4 and can be written as (1+11i) + (2+22i)*x + (3+33i)*x^2 + 44i*x^3 + 55i*x^4
      Parameters:
      coef_re - An array containing the real part of the coefficients in order of increasing power. If the supplied array equals null, then the degree is determined by the length of the other array and the real part of all coefficients equals 0 in that case.
      coef_im - An array containing the imaginary part of the coefficients in order of increasing power. If the supplied array equals null, then the degree is determined by the length of the other array and the imaginary part of all coefficients equals 0 in that case.

    • PZeros

      public PZeros(DoubleComplex[] coef)
      Constructor that takes an array of complex coefficients. Coefficients are supplied in order of increasing power. Example: p(x) = A + B*x + C*x^2 + D*x^3 + E*x^4 can be created with coef[] = {A, B, C, D, E}. The degree of the polynomial is equal to the length of the supplied array minus 1.
      Parameters:
      coef - An array of complex coefficients in order of increasing power.

      Parameters:
      coef - An array of complex coefficients in order of increasing power.

  • Method Details

    • degree

      public int degree()
      Returns the degree of the polynomial.
      Returns:
      The degree of the polynomial.

    • solve

      public int solve(DoubleComplex[] root, double[] radius, boolean[] err)
      This method computes the roots of the polynomial and stores the roots in preallocated arrays, which are passed as arguments. DoubleDouble 105-bit precision is used for the calculations and the results also are returned at DoubleDouble precision.
      Parameters:
      root - Array, in which the zeros will be stored after computation of the zeros. This array must have a length of at least N elements, where N is the degree of the polynomial.
      radius - Array, which gives an indication of the accuracy of the found roots. For each root, a radius is returned. The root is assured to be in the disk with the corresponding radius, centered around the returned root.
      err - Array, which specifies whether the root and its corresponding radius of accuracy could be determined correctly. If err[i] is true, then the program did not converge for root[i].
      Returns:
      Returns the degree of the polynomial if the computation succeeds, and returns a value less than the degree of the polynomial if an error occurs (e.g. convergence failure). When a value less than the degree of the polynomial is returned, then only part (or none) of the roots could be determined. If a negative value is returned, then the supplied input is not correct: -1: Leading coefficient equals 0. -2: Coefficient for x^0 (constant coefficient) equals 0. -3: Ratio of smallest coefficient magnitude and largest coefficient magnitude is too large and will lead to underflow/overflow.

    • solve

      public int solve(Complex[] root, double[] radius, boolean[] err)
      This method computes the roots of the polynomial and stores the roots in preallocated arrays, which are passed as arguments. Standard 53-bits precision is used for the calculations and the results also are returned as standard 53-bits precision numbers.
      Parameters:
      root - Array, in which the zeros will be stored after computation of the zeros. This array must have a length of at least N elements, where N is the degree of the polynomial.
      radius - Array, which gives an indication of the accuracy of the found roots. For each root, a radius is returned. The root is assured to be in the disk with the corresponding radius, centered around the returned root.
      err - Array, which specifies whether the root and its corresponding radius of accuracy could be determined correctly. If err[i] is true, then the program did not converge for root[i].
      Returns:
      Returns the degree of the polynomial if the computation succeeds, and returns a value less than the degree of the polynomial if an error occurs (e.g. convergence failure). When a value less than the degree of the polynomial is returned, then only part (or none) of the roots could be determined. If a negative value is returned, then the supplied input is not correct: -1: Leading coefficient equals 0. -2: Coefficient for x^0 (constant coefficient) equals 0. -3: Ratio of smallest coefficient magnitude and largest coefficient magnitude is too large and will lead to underflow/overflow.
